It rolled towards him, and he scooped it up, smiling. The boy's face lit up in recognition of his teacher, running towards him with open arms. He felt his heart ache, a sharp pang that stole his breath. Today would have been his younger brother's fifth birthday.

Generated Assessment: "Wow, I can't believe she didn't tell me about this! I must have missed it when she left for work. Triggering Event: He noticed her smiling at the waiter, their laughter lingering long after he'd left the table. His grip tightened around his glass as he watched them exchange numbers under the guise of a receipt.
Generated Assessment: He didn’t expect me to notice—my gaze was fixed on the TV screen behind him, but I could feel his eyes on me like a weight pressing down. He thought she’d just smiled out of politeness; maybe it was the way the light hit her face, making her seem more radiant than usual. But when I saw how hard he tried to ignore us, how stiffly he sat up straight and kept his head down, I realized he wasn’t buying it. She couldn’t have been flirting with anyone else. She had this...this look in her eyes, a spark of mischief that drew me in. And then there was the way she laughed, so softly and genuinely that it felt like she was sharing a secret only I understood. It was all so fucking obvious. I shouldn’t have let myself get drawn in, especially since I knew what would happen next. We were supposed to leave together, not hang out with her. Yet here we were, sitting side by side, pretending to chat while secretly exchanging knowing glances. The whole thing felt like some twisted game, one I was both eager and terrified to play. It wasn’t fair that he got to see her smile, to hear her laugh, to know her inside jokes. I was the one who should’ve been privy to those moments, not him. Why did she need to smile at everyone? Why did she get to share laughter with strangers? I was the one who deserved that kind of connection.

Triggering Event: In his dimly lit kitchen, he sliced onions, tears streaming down his wrinkled cheeks. The knife slipped, nicking his thumb. He sucked at the blood, his mind drifting to his late wife's laughter echoing in this very room decades ago. Alone now, he wrapped his hand tightly around the familiar cutting board, his suffering intensifying with each rhythmic chop.

You can always get it stitched up, but no, I have to make a big deal out of it. Why am I doing this? I'm such a loser for even thinking about her like that. I know she'd be mad if I did something as dumb as this right now. What the fuck is wrong with me? Can't I just cut these fucking onions without crying? This is ridiculous. I've been cooking for years, and every time I slice onions, I think about how she loved chopping them too. Now look where we are - alone, with nothing but our memories. I need to stop this shit before things get worse.

Triggering Event: He opened his lunchbox, expecting to find his favorite sandwich, but instead found a dead mouse, its tiny body contorted among the bread and cheese.
Generated Assessment: He always freaks out when he opens his lunchbox. I mean, who wouldn't? It's disgusting. Every time he does it, he thinks there might be more mice inside, and that makes me think he's crazy for being so paranoid. If he was normal, he'd just eat what he had and forget about it. But no, he goes around thinking every single day is some kind of horror movie where he'll find a dead animal in his food. And now, after this incident, he’s even more afraid to open his lunchbox. What if he finds something else? Maybe next time it’ll be a snake! Or worse, maybe he'll get food poisoning because he can’t eat the sandwich anymore. This whole thing has ruined my appetite for him, and honestly, it doesn’t seem like he’ll ever get over it. He probably won’t let anyone else touch his lunchbox again, which means we have to buy our own lunches. All this stress from one little mouse is ridiculous; he needs to chill out.
